III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff sufficiency
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10123
Section (1) A facility shall have a staffing pattern of administrative,
Description supervisory, direct care, and other staff sufficient to perform
the prescribed functions required by these administrative rules
and to provide for the needs, protection, and supervision of the
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 08/17/2024 Youth A touched Youth D inappropriately while
under the supervision of staff.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 09/05/2024 and had no
additional information to share.
Youth A was interviewed on 08/29/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled sitting with Youth D
during the incident in question. He stated they were sitting next to
each other at a table. Youth A confirmed he was attempting to
touch Youth D under the table and was able to touch her knee and
upper leg over her clothes. Youth A believed this was not easy to
see. He stated he and Youth D were trying to be sneaky and
avoid staff noticing them. Youth A had heard staff tell him multiple
times they have eyes on youth at all times, so he knew they could
get caught. He has seen staff members correct other youth
touching each other in similar ways. Youth A stated this behavior
was not pre-planned with Youth D.
Youth B was interviewed on 08/29/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled the incident in
question, remembering seeing Youth A and Youth D sitting next to
each other at a table within the unit. He stated that he did not see
anyone touch each other, however. Youth B confirmed that any
physical contact between youth is not allowed. He did not believe
youth could “sneak” any contact between each other, either,
because of how well youth are supervised.
Youth C was interviewed on 08/29/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth C recalled witnessing the
incident in question. He believed he saw Youth A able to touch
2

Youth D underneath her clothing while sitting next to each other.
Youth C was not able to state how he knew that Youth A had his
hand underneath the pants of Youth D. He stated this occurred
for a minute or so, and staff did not appear to notice despite sitting
nearby. Youth C recalled Youth A and Youth D being quiet while
this was occurring. Youth C did not say anything about this
behavior at the time. He confirmed that this would not normally
occur.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone on 10/01/2024. She
recalled being placed at the facility with Youth A prior to her new
placement but denied there ever being a time when she or Youth
A touched each other in the manner alleged. Youth D recalled
there being rules in the facility about youth not touching each
other in any manner. She also stated there were not any rules
about youth sitting next to each other. Youth D believed the rules
about no touching were often broken by youth, and sometimes
staff noticed and told youth about it, sometimes staff did not state
anything to youth about it and sometimes it was not noticed at all.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 10/14/2024. She
stated she was alerted to the incident and read the incident report
documentation about it after the fact, but did not see it occur while
with the youth on the date in question. She confirmed she was
working with the youth and was present when this would have
occurred. Staff 1 confirmed youth are not allowed any physical
contact, and that she often would point this out to youth. This
most commonly occurred with youth “horseplaying” and would end
quickly with staff verbalizing the rules and reminding them. She
also stated it was common for staff to have to separate youth who
had broken this rule or had given staff reason to be concerned.
Staff 1 stated she would have separated Youth A and Youth D
had she noticed this touching occurring, either having them move
altogether or had them sit across from each other had she noticed
what was occurring.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 10/23/2024. Staff 2
stated he was alerted to the behavior of Youth A and Youth D on
the date in question, but he did not see it occur. He confirmed he
was working in the same unit with these two youth when this
occurred. Staff 2 reviewed the video footage and saw himself
walking past Youth A and Youth D, but he did not see the
behavior occurring. Staff 2 stated it was common for youth to
break the no touching rule, but not usually in this manner. Staff 2
stated it was more common that youth of the same sex showed
“horseplaying” behavior and would have to be called out by staff.
3

Staff 2 believed this behavior should have been noticed and called
out to stop it, and he stated that it would have been easy to
prevent from occurring further after noticing it.
Video reviewed:
• Video footage showing the unit on 08/17/2024 was
provided and reviewed. During the footage various youth
were seen in the common area of the unit. Youth A and
Youth D were seen sitting next to each other at a small
round table. Over the course of about two minutes both
Youth A and Youth D could be seen reaching under the
table to touch the other. It did not appear they were able to
do so underneath their clothing as the arm movements of
both youths were quick and not demonstrative, and it did
not appear that their clothing moved around. Their
movements and contact could not be fully seen as their
hands and lower bodies were obscured by the table itself.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were both seen intermittently in the
footage, in view of Youth A and Youth D.
Documentation reviewed:
• Incident report documentation was provided and reviewed.
It stated that on 08/18/2024 Youth C reported to a staff
member that he had witnessed Youth A and Youth D
touching each other on 08/17/2024. In this documentation
Youth C reported that this touching was sexual in nature.
• Facility policy and procedure titles Juvenile Supervision and
Movement was provided and reviewed. In this policy it was
stated that staff “shall be aware of the location of all
juveniles at all times” and that staff “shall have visual
contact with each juvenile.”
• Facility handbook documentation for youth was provided
and reviewed. This documentation is provided to youth at
the time of placement and stated that “there must be no
physical contact among residents.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews, documentation and video reviewed. There was no
evidence found that staff were not providing supervision of the
youth as described in the rule.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility is advised to use this incident as training
material regarding staff supervision of youth, focusing on
adherence to expectations provided to youth, placement of
youth or sitting areas to help reduce the chance of youth’s
4

physical contact and examining any possible blind spots
while staff are supervising youth.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
